Purpose of Obtaining Medical Examinations and Opinions
The submission of a substantially complete claim triggers the duty of the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to assist a claimant in obtaining a medical examination or opinion when necessary to substantiate the claim.
Exception
:  An examination or opinion is not part of the duty to assist in a supplemental claim unless new and relevant evidence is presented or secured.
The purpose is to obtain medical evidence relevant to establishing entitlement to benefits, when the evidence of record is not sufficient to make a decision, such as information about
diagnosis
onset, or
etiology.
References
:  For more information on
supplemental claims, see
M21-1, Part II, Subpart iii, 2.B
the duty to assist in providing an examination or opinion, see
38 U.S.C. 5103A(d)
, and
38 CFR 3.159(c)(4)
requesting a medical opinion or examination, see
M21-1, Part IV, Subpart i, 2.A
scheduling a medical opinion or examination, see
M21-1, Part IV, Subpart i, 2.B
circumstances when VA may refrain from providing assistance, see
M21-1, Part I, Subpart i, 1.A.4.b
, and
definitions of types of medical assessments, see
M21-1, Part V, Subpart ii, 1.A.3.b
.
